channel.title: Smallest memory allocation?
channel.description:
Hello, I'm trying to create an extremely large array. It is quite necessary for my application. This is what I have.
[code]byte cartisian[][][] = new byte[2][5000][5000][/code]
Before I tried
[code]boolean cartisian[][][] = new boolean[2][5000][5000][/code]
When I use a loop to go through all of them, it creates a Java heap space error. Also, I don't want my application going over 80mb in memory allocation. What should I do?

item.title: Smallest memory allocation?
item.dc:creator: @BAsh_CntLgn BAsh(CntLgn)
item.description:
@BAsh_CntLgn wrote:

16bits = 0 to 65535.

For Rajae’s purposes this is probably the largest value he would possible use. Given that the value would never be negative it makes sense. It also uses half the space which is what he is trying to reduce. Rajae have not looked at the client so I wish you luck at ripping the data you need out of it.

Read full topic

item.title: Smallest memory allocation?
item.dc:creator: @_cake _cake
item.description:
@_cake wrote:

bash, no, char in java takes up same amount of memory as int, but is limited in value range (amount of bits allowed to be used).

Read full topic

I rounded.

item.title: Smallest memory allocation?
item.dc:creator: @Rajae Rajae
item.description:
@Rajae wrote:

BAsh(CntLgn):

Not mem usage but the algorithm - is it fast and whats you pc like?

I’m working on my waypoint system, so I don’t know how good it is. (Help with that’d be great :o)

My PC:
3.2GHz Pentium 4
NVidia 128 - 512mb PCI-E
AC97
80GB hard drive
160GB portable hard drive
1gb RAM

Read full topic

item.title: Smallest memory allocation?
item.dc:creator: @BAsh_CntLgn BAsh(CntLgn)
item.description:
@BAsh_CntLgn wrote:

Not mem usage but the algorithm - is it fast and whats you pc like?

Edit: use a char[] rather than an int[] - it takes up less space. It is unlikely that you will need to use anything larger than that 65000 and its unsigned which is good. When I ran it on my comp i got 48Mb or so but the calculator says about 44Mb so I would say there is some extra performance you could squeeze out. There again I tried it with an half size int[] and it was still that size so maybe you shouldn’t bother - let the jvm do the conversions and prevent overflows into adjacent cells. Tried with long[] as well - same thing.

Read full topic

item.title: Smallest memory allocation?
item.dc:creator: @Rajae Rajae
item.description:
@Rajae wrote:

[quote=“BAsh(CntLgn), post:18, topic:160990”]I got 2.7Mb on my calc but in the vm it came to 2.9Mb - bit of overhead but who cares.

Sweet optimization k00dr. It looks like Rajae has given the game away lol - tell me what performance you get off that thing will you?[/quote]

It’s quite good. Using a 15000*15000 array, it only takes up around 27mb. Quite good! But I get more troubling algorithms to work out now.

Read full topic

item.title: Smallest memory allocation?
item.dc:creator: @Rajae Rajae
item.description:
@Rajae wrote:

[quote=“k00dr, post:16, topic:160990”]I wrote you a working example

[code]/*
remove the “unnecessary” local variables to optimize the code.
I kept them in to keep it simple.
*/

public final class BitsetGrid {

private final int width;

private final int height;

private final int[] grid;

public BitsetGrid(int width, int height) {
this.width = width;
this.height = height;
int tmp = width * height;
int n = tmp / 32; //optimize performance with tmp >>> 5
int k = tmp % 32; //optimize performance with tmp & 0x1f
if(k > 0)
n++;
grid = new int[n];
}

public final int getWidth() {
return width;
}

public final int getHeight() {
return height;
}

public final boolean get(int idx) {
int n = idx / 32; //optimize performance with idx >>> 5
int k = idx % 32; //optimize performance with idx & 0x1f
return (grid[n] & (1 << k)) != 0;
}

public final void set(int idx, boolean flag) {
int n = idx / 32; //optimize performance with idx >>> 5
int k = idx % 32; //optimize performance with idx & 0x1f
if(flag)
grid[n] |= 1 << k;
else
grid[n] &= ~(1 << k);
}

public final boolean get(int x, int y) {
return get(y * width + x);
}

public final void set(int x, int y, boolean flag) {
set(y * width + x, flag);
}

}[/code][/quote]

Wow, thanks k00dr! That was very helpful! You saved me a lot of thinking and researching :).

Now it’s time for me to figure out how to make auto waypoints…

Read full topic

item.title: Smallest memory allocation?
item.dc:creator: @k00dr k00dr
item.description:
@k00dr wrote:

I wrote you a working example

[code]/*
remove the “unnecessary” local variables to optimize the code.
I kept them in to keep it simple.
*/

public final class BitsetGrid {

private final int width;

private final int height;

private final int[] grid;

public BitsetGrid(int width, int height) {
this.width = width;
this.height = height;
int tmp = width * height;
int n = tmp / 32; //optimize performance with tmp >>> 5
int k = tmp % 32; //optimize performance with tmp & 0x1f
if(k > 0)
n++;
grid = new int[n];
}

public final int getWidth() {
return width;
}

public final int getHeight() {
return height;
}

public final boolean get(int idx) {
int n = idx / 32; //optimize performance with idx >>> 5
int k = idx % 32; //optimize performance with idx & 0x1f
return (grid[n] & (1 << k)) != 0;
}

public final void set(int idx, boolean flag) {
int n = idx / 32; //optimize performance with idx >>> 5
int k = idx % 32; //optimize performance with idx & 0x1f
if(flag)
grid[n] |= 1 << k;
else
grid[n] &= ~(1 << k);
}

public final boolean get(int x, int y) {
return get(y * width + x);
}

public final void set(int x, int y, boolean flag) {
set(y * width + x, flag);
}

}[/code]

Read full topic

item.description:
@Rajae wrote:

No, I’m trying to create a double floored grid. The arrays are there to represent a false or true boolean to each coordinate, meaning that if they are walled or empty.

item.title: Smallest memory allocation?
item.dc:creator: @speedster239 speedster239
item.description:
@speedster239 wrote:

Do you need to access all of the data in the array at once?

Read full topic

item.title: Smallest memory allocation?
item.dc:creator: @Rajae Rajae
item.description:
@Rajae wrote:

Iamadam:

I’m just curious as to why you need a 50MB array?

An extremely large 2-floor minesweeper-like grid…

Also, when I tried using an int, it took more than 500mb on initialize… Booleans took around 300mb. Bytes only 200mb. Bytes seem to be the smallest to use.

I think I can just use this so its not 250005000

public boolean xCoord[][] = new boolean[2][5000]; public boolean yCoord[][] = new boolean[2][5000];

So it wouldn’t be over 1 million arrays. Instead it would be 10000, right?
Seemed neater to me to use boolean[][][]

EDIT: This seems to work quite well… Only 2MB used from this. Effective for me. I learned from my mistake
EDIT2: Nevermind… It seems like I need the triple boolean.
EDIT3: Would it be possible to create an array byte so I don’t need so many array of bytes? If so, how do I do that? I’m not too good with bytes.

Read full topic

item.title: Smallest memory allocation?
item.dc:creator: @BAsh_CntLgn BAsh(CntLgn)
item.description:
@BAsh_CntLgn wrote:

Does the VM store booleans internally as ints or booleans when in array form?

Be aware that you have 2*5000 object references in addition to the booleans and these are stored as 32bit ints.

Read full topic

item.title: Smallest memory allocation?
item.dc:creator: @Iamadam Iamadam
item.description:
@Iamadam wrote:

I’m just curious as to why you need a 50MB array?

item.title: Smallest memory allocation?
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

[quote="_cake, post:7, topic:160990"]neither, the vm treats both as ints.[/quote]on the stack, yes, in the heap, no

Read full topic

item.title: Smallest memory allocation?
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

be very careful here, it treats them as ints when storing them on the operand stack, but it treats them as whatever type they are when storing them in variables.

Read full topic

item.title: Smallest memory allocation?
item.dc:creator: @_cake _cake
item.description:
@_cake wrote:

neither, the vm treats both as ints.

Read full topic

item.title: Smallest memory allocation?
item.dc:creator: @BAsh_CntLgn BAsh(CntLgn)
item.description:
@BAsh_CntLgn wrote:

Use a [2][5000] of BitSet. An alternative approach is to take slices of it and send it to disk. Then read it back on the fly as your process it.

Read full topic

item.description:
@yakman wrote:

what frank_ said,

you could also try a linked list structure if you want to store a load of stuff, but that wont work if you want to access them by their index, (so like myList[5] wont work so well with a linked list)

depending on what data you are actually storing, you might try some form of bit-packing

There are several ways to optimize code away from large arrays, but it depends on what your code looks like and what you’re trying to accomplish.
